stair.title: Stair Calculator
stair.description: Calculate staircase dimensions including riser height, tread depth, and number of steps for safe stair design.
stair.unit_tooltip: Select centimeters or inches for measurements
stair.total_rise_tooltip: Vertical distance from bottom to top floor
stair.desired_riser_height_tooltip: Preferred height of each step (typically 17-19cm or 7-7.5in)

compliance.compliant: Stair dimensions meet standard building codes
compliance.riser_too_low: Warning: Riser height is below minimum (10cm/4in)
compliance.tread_too_shallow: Warning: Tread depth is below minimum (25.4cm/10in)

stair.formula: Steps = Total Rise / Riser Height. Tread Depth uses the comfort rule: 2R + T = 63.5cm (25in).
stair.info_description: Proper stair design ensures safety and comfort. The comfort rule (2R + T = 25in) provides optimal riser-to-tread ratio for easy climbing.

errors.invalid_rise: Please enter a valid total rise
errors.positive_values: Values must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_riser_height: Please enter a valid riser height

howItWorks.title: How the Stair Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Steps = Total Rise / Riser Height; Tread Depth = 63.5cm - (2 × Riser Height)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines the optimal number of steps and dimensions using the comfort rule (2R + T = 63.5cm). It ensures stairs meet building codes for safe, comfortable climbing.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Measure total rise (floor-to-floor height)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter desired riser height (17-19cm ideal)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Review calculated step count and dimensions

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Check building code compliance warnings

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Adjust riser height if needed for whole steps

useCases.title: Interior Staircases
useCases.description: Design code-compliant stairs between floors in homes and buildings.

useCases.title: Deck and Porch Steps
useCases.description: Calculate outdoor stair dimensions for proper rise and run.

useCases.title: Basement Access
useCases.description: Plan stairs for basement entry with often limited headroom.

useCases.title: Building Permits
useCases.description: Verify stair designs meet local building code requirements.

seoTips: Ideal riser height is 17-19cm (7-7.5 inches) for comfortable climbing
Use the comfort rule: 2 × Riser + Tread = 63.5cm (25 inches)
All risers must be uniform height - code allows max 3/8 inch variance
Minimum tread depth is 25.4cm (10 inches) per most building codes
Consider headroom requirements - minimum 6'8" (203cm) clearance

commonMistakes.solution: Calculate exact rise per step - all risers must be within 3/8 inch of each other
Maintain minimum 10-inch (25.4cm) tread depth for safety
Add 3/4 to 1-1/4 inch nosing overhang to effective tread depth
Ensure 6'8" minimum headroom throughout the stairway

faqs.question: What is the ideal stair riser height?
faqs.answer: The ideal riser height is 17-19cm (7-7.5 inches). Building codes typically allow 10-19.7cm (4-7.75 inches) maximum.

faqs.question: What is the 2R + T rule for stairs?
faqs.answer: The comfort rule states that 2 × Riser Height + Tread Depth should equal approximately 63.5cm (25 inches) for comfortable climbing.

faqs.question: How many steps do I need for a 9-foot ceiling?
faqs.answer: For a 9-foot (274cm) floor-to-floor rise with 18cm risers, you need approximately 15-16 steps.

faqs.question: What is the maximum stair angle allowed?
faqs.answer: Most codes limit residential stairs to 42 degrees. Steeper angles are uncomfortable and potentially hazardous.

faqs.question: Do I need a landing in my staircase?
faqs.answer: Landings are required when stairs exceed 12 feet (3.7m) vertical rise. They must be at least as deep as the stair width.

stringer.title: Stringer Calculator
stringer.description: Calculate stair stringer dimensions including length, angle, and layout for proper stair construction.
stringer.unit_tooltip: Select centimeters or inches for measurements
stringer.total_rise_tooltip: Vertical distance from bottom to top of stairs
stringer.total_run_tooltip: Horizontal distance from first to last step
stringer.number_of_steps_tooltip: Total number of steps/risers in the staircase
stringer.throat_warning: Warning: Throat width is below the recommended minimum of 8.9cm (3.5in). Consider using wider lumber for structural integrity.
stringer.formula: Stringer Length = √(Rise² + Run²). Board length includes 10% safety margin for cutting.
stringer.info_description: Accurate stringer calculations ensure proper stair construction. The Pythagorean theorem determines the exact length needed, while throat width ensures structural integrity.

errors.invalid_dimensions: Please enter valid rise and run dimensions
errors.positive_values: Dimensions must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_width: Stringer width must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_steps: Number of steps must be at least 2

howItWorks.title: How the Stringer Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator uses the Pythagorean theorem to determine stair stringer length. It also calculates the cutting angle, throat width, and recommends appropriate lumber sizes for structural integrity.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter total rise (vertical height)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter total run (horizontal distance)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Specify number of steps

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Set stringer board width (2x12 typical)

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Review stringer length and cutting dimensions

useCases.title: Custom Stair Building
useCases.description: Calculate precise stringer dimensions for custom residential stairs.

useCases.title: Deck Stair Construction
useCases.description: Determine stringer requirements for exterior deck access stairs.

useCases.title: Lumber Purchasing
useCases.description: Know exact board lengths needed before buying stringer material.

useCases.title: Carpentry Layout
useCases.description: Get cutting angles and dimensions for accurate stringer fabrication.

seoTips: Use 2x12 lumber for stringers to maintain adequate throat width
Minimum throat width should be 3.5 inches (8.9cm) for structural integrity
Cut stringers from straight, clear lumber without large knots
Use metal stringer brackets at top and bottom for secure attachment
Most codes require minimum 3 stringers for stairs wider than 36 inches

commonMistakes.solution: Use wider lumber or adjust rise/run to maintain 3.5 inch minimum throat
Select straight, clear boards - knots at cuts weaken stringers
Use 3 stringers for stairs over 30 inches wide, 4 for over 45 inches
Use approved metal connectors at top and bottom, not just nails

faqs.question: What size lumber should I use for stair stringers?
faqs.answer: 2x12 boards are standard for most residential stairs. They provide adequate throat width after cutting notches for typical rise and run dimensions.

faqs.question: What is throat width and why does it matter?
faqs.answer: Throat width is the narrowest part of the stringer after cutting. It must be at least 3.5 inches (8.9cm) for structural integrity.

faqs.question: How many stringers do I need?
faqs.answer: Use 2 stringers for stairs up to 30 inches wide, 3 stringers for 30-45 inches, and 4 stringers for wider stairs.

faqs.question: How do I mark stringer cuts?
faqs.answer: Use a framing square with stair gauges set to your rise and run measurements. Mark each step consistently along the board.

faqs.question: Should I drop the first riser?
faqs.answer: Yes, drop the bottom of the stringer by one tread thickness so the first step height equals all other steps after tread installation.

fence.title: Fence Calculator
fence.description: Calculate fence materials including posts, panels, and rails needed for your fencing project.
fence.unit_tooltip: Select meters or feet for measurements
fence.fence_length_tooltip: Total length of the fence line
fence.fence_height_tooltip: Height of the fence above ground
fence.panel_width_tooltip: Width of each fence panel (typically 1.8m or 6ft)
fence.formula: Posts = (Length / Spacing) + 1. Panels = Length / Panel Width. Rails depend on fence height.
fence.info_description: Accurate fence material estimation ensures you have enough posts, panels, and rails. Post spacing and panel width vary by fence type and local codes.

errors.positive_values: Dimensions must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_spacing: Post spacing must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_panel_width: Panel width must be greater than zero

howItWorks.title: How the Fence Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Posts = (Length / Spacing) + 1; Panels = Length / Panel Width
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines the number of posts, panels, and rails needed based on fence length and standard spacing intervals. It also estimates concrete requirements for post installation.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Measure the total fence line length

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter fence height (above ground)

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Specify post spacing (typically 6-8 feet)

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Set panel width based on your fence type

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Review posts, panels, rails, and concrete needed

useCases.title: Privacy Fencing
useCases.description: Calculate materials for 6-foot privacy fences around residential properties.

useCases.title: Picket Fences
useCases.description: Estimate pickets, posts, and rails for decorative front yard fencing.

useCases.title: Pool Enclosures
useCases.description: Plan code-compliant pool fencing with proper height and gate allowances.

useCases.title: Farm and Ranch Fencing
useCases.description: Calculate post and rail quantities for large agricultural fencing projects.

seoTips: Set posts at least 1/3 of total post length below ground for stability
Use pressure-treated or cedar posts for ground contact to prevent rot
Space posts 6-8 feet apart for most residential fencing applications
Check local codes for fence height limits and setback requirements
Add extra posts at corners and gate locations for reinforcement

commonMistakes.solution: Bury posts 1/3 of their length (minimum 2 feet) for stability
Set posts in concrete for wind resistance and longevity
Add extra posts and hardware for each gate location
Verify property boundaries before installation to avoid disputes

faqs.question: How deep should fence posts be?
faqs.answer: Fence posts should be buried 1/3 of their total length, with a minimum of 2 feet. For a 6-foot fence, use 8-foot posts with 2 feet below ground.

faqs.question: How much concrete per fence post?
faqs.answer: Each post typically requires 1-2 bags (40-80 lbs) of concrete, depending on hole size. A 10-inch diameter hole, 2 feet deep needs about 1.5 bags.

faqs.question: What is the standard fence post spacing?
faqs.answer: Standard spacing is 6-8 feet between posts for most residential fences. Shorter spacing provides more stability in high-wind areas.

faqs.question: Do I need a permit for a fence?
faqs.answer: Most areas require permits for fences over 6 feet. Check local codes for height limits, setback requirements, and permit needs.

faqs.question: How long does a wooden fence last?
faqs.answer: Cedar fences last 15-20 years, pressure-treated pine 15-20 years, and untreated pine 5-10 years. Proper maintenance extends lifespan.

lumber.title: Lumber Calculator
lumber.description: Calculate board feet and lumber quantities for framing and construction projects.
lumber.unit_tooltip: Select measurement unit for lumber dimensions
lumber.length_tooltip: Length of each piece in feet
lumber.formula: Board Feet = (Thickness × Width × Length) / 12. For dimensional lumber in inches and feet.
lumber.info_description: Board feet is the standard unit for lumber volume. Understanding board feet helps estimate costs and plan material orders.

errors.positive_values: Values must be greater than zero

howItWorks.title: How the Lumber Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Board Feet = (Thickness × Width × Length in inches) / 144
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator converts lumber dimensions to board feet, the standard volume measurement for lumber. It helps estimate material quantities and costs for construction projects.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Select lumber dimension or enter custom size

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Enter number of pieces needed

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Specify length of each piece

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Review total board feet and linear feet

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Use board feet for cost estimation

useCases.title: Wall Framing
useCases.description: Calculate studs for interior and exterior wall framing.

useCases.title: Floor Joist Systems
useCases.description: Estimate joist quantities for floor and ceiling framing.

useCases.title: Deck Construction
useCases.description: Plan lumber needs for deck framing and railing.

useCases.title: Woodworking Projects
useCases.description: Calculate board feet for furniture and custom millwork.

seoTips: Nominal dimensions differ from actual - 2×4 is actually 1.5×3.5 inches
Kiln-dried lumber (KD) is preferred for interior framing
Pressure-treated lumber is required for ground contact and exterior use
Standard stud spacing is 16 inches on center, 24 inches for some applications
Order 5-10% extra lumber for waste, warped boards, and cutting

commonMistakes.mistake: Using nominal instead of actual dimensions
commonMistakes.solution: A 2×4 is actually 1.5×3.5 inches - use actual for precise calculations
Sight down each board for crowns, twists, and warps before purchasing
Use pressure-treated for exterior, SPF for interior framing
Size headers based on span and load - consult span tables

faqs.question: What is a board foot of lumber?
faqs.answer: A board foot equals 144 cubic inches (1 inch thick × 12 inches wide × 12 inches long). It is the standard unit for lumber volume and pricing.

faqs.question: How many 2×4s in a wall?
faqs.answer: For 16-inch on center spacing, divide wall length (in inches) by 16, add 1 for the end, plus extra for headers, cripples, and corners.

faqs.question: What is the actual size of a 2×4?
faqs.answer: Actual dimensions are 1.5×3.5 inches (38×89mm). Nominal sizes are pre-drying dimensions that changed due to processing.

faqs.question: How much does lumber weigh?
faqs.answer: Softwood lumber (pine, fir) weighs approximately 2.5-3 lbs per board foot when dried. Green lumber is heavier.

faqs.question: What is the difference between SPF and treated lumber?
faqs.answer: SPF (Spruce-Pine-Fir) is untreated softwood for interior use. Pressure-treated lumber has preservatives for moisture and insect resistance in exterior applications.

deck.title: Deck Calculator
deck.description: Calculate decking boards, joists, posts, and fasteners for outdoor deck construction.
deck.unit_tooltip: Select meters or feet for deck dimensions
deck.board_size_tooltip: Select the size of decking boards
deck.waste_factor_tooltip: Extra material for cuts and waste (typically 10-15%)
deck.formula: Deck Area = Length × Width. Boards = (Area / Board Coverage) × (1 + Waste). Joists based on spacing.
deck.info_description: This calculator estimates all materials needed for deck construction including boards, framing lumber, posts, and fasteners based on your deck dimensions.
deck.use_case_3: Pool surrounds and outdoor living spaces

errors.positive_values: Dimensions must be greater than zero
errors.invalid_board_length: Please enter a valid board length
errors.invalid_waste: Waste factor must be between 0 and 50%

howItWorks.title: How the Deck Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Decking Boards = (Deck Area / Board Coverage) × (1 + Waste)
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines decking boards based on surface area and board width. It also calculates joists, beams, posts, and fasteners needed for complete deck construction.

steps.name: Step 1
steps.text: Enter deck length and width dimensions

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Select decking board width

steps.name: Step 3
steps.text: Choose joist spacing (16 inches is standard)

steps.name: Step 4
steps.text: Set waste factor for cuts and scrap

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Review all materials: boards, framing, fasteners

useCases.title: Ground-Level Deck
useCases.description: Calculate materials for freestanding ground-level decks.

useCases.title: Elevated Deck
useCases.description: Plan materials for raised decks with post and beam framing.

useCases.title: Multi-Level Deck
useCases.description: Estimate materials for complex multi-tier deck designs.

useCases.title: Deck Replacement
useCases.description: Determine decking board quantities for surface replacement.

seoTips: Use 16-inch joist spacing for most decking materials
Composite and PVC decking may require 12-inch spacing - check manufacturer specs
Posts should be set in concrete at least 42 inches deep in cold climates
Leave 1/8-inch gap between boards for drainage and expansion
Use stainless steel or coated screws with pressure-treated and composite decking

commonMistakes.solution: Follow decking manufacturer recommendations - typically 16 inches maximum
Set posts below frost line (42+ inches) to prevent heaving
Use approved screws for your decking type - ACQ-compatible for treated lumber
Install deck with slight slope (1/8 inch per foot) away from house

faqs.question: How many deck boards do I need?
faqs.answer: Divide deck square footage by board coverage (5.5-inch board covers 0.46 sq ft per linear foot). Add 10-15% for waste.

faqs.question: What size joists for a deck?
faqs.answer: 2×8 joists span up to 12 feet, 2×10 up to 15 feet, 2×12 up to 18 feet at 16-inch spacing. Check local codes for specific requirements.

faqs.question: How many screws per deck board?
faqs.answer: Use 2 screws per joist crossing. A 12-foot board across 9 joists needs 18 screws. Plan for approximately 350 screws per 100 sq ft of decking.

faqs.question: Should I use treated lumber or composite?
faqs.answer: Treated lumber costs less initially but requires maintenance. Composite costs more but is low-maintenance and lasts longer.

faqs.question: Do I need a permit for a deck?
faqs.answer: Most areas require permits for decks over 200 sq ft or more than 30 inches above grade. Check local building codes.
